title: Fur coats, an opera and a builder's workshop as Turner Prize exhibition opens
text:
Fur coats, an opera and a builder's workshop as Turner Prize exhibition opens Fur coats, an opera and a builder's workshop as Turner Prize exhibition opens 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
It has a reputation for controversy, with previous winning works including dead animals and lights switching on and off, and the Turner Prize still knows how to pull an audience. 
This year Bonnie Camplin, Janice Kerbel, Nicole Wermers and collective Assemble are in the running for the £25,000 prize, and it’s being staged in Glasgow for the first time. 
— Paul Ward (@paulward21) September 30, 2015 
Wermers’s installation is the first to be seen at Glasgow’s Tramway and could be mistaken for a cloakroom. Infrastruktur by Turner Prize nominee Nicole Wermers (Andy Milligan/PA) 
Infrastruktur features a series of chairs with expensive fur coats hanging over the back. It may look like a living room during a party but those “in the know” say it “exposes the way that we as a society… have been reduced to making judgements on commercial aesthetics”. 
Then there’s Camplin’s The Military Industrial Complex. It sounds scary but turns out to be a study room “drawing from physics, philosophy, psychology, witchcraft, quantum theory and warfare” on issues around mental health. A visitor views The Military Industrial Complex by Bonnie Camplin (Andy Milligan/PA) 
The exhibition includes large TVs – playing conspiracy theories on loop – books and a photocopier spread across a room. 
Living art is also involved, with Kerbel nominated for her operatic performance work Doug, made up of nine songs sung by six voices. The first visitors watch a performance of Doug by Janice Kerbel (Andy Milligan/PA) 
But the favourite for the award is Assemble, who have moved a housing estate workshop from Liverpool to Glasgow for their exhibition. 
The group were nominated for work to transform part of the Toxteth estate – Granby Four Streets – which fell into disrepair after riots over 20 years ago. Members of Assemble sit inside their exhibit (Andy Milligan/PA) 
Residents fought plans for demolition and Assemble were invited to help locals regenerate the housing and public spaces “from the ground up”. 
Visitors to the Assemble exhibition can buy the goods on display as the group use the Turner Prize to start a social enterprise and fund further regeneration in Toxteth. Assemble have moved their workshop from Liverpool to Glasgow (Andy Milligan/PA) Share article 
The exhibition is running in Glasgow’s Tramway, with the winner of the prestigious £25,000 prize to be announced in December. Promoted Stories
